headline: Joe Biden accuses Elizabeth Warren of 'elitism'
subHeadline: Biden slams Democratic presidential rival Elizabeth Warren for Warren's claim that Biden was running in the wrong presidential primary; reaction on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: LAFE LANGFORD, RELATED TO VICTIMS KILLED IN MEXICO
utterances.sentences: The vehicles that had left our community were, we believe they may have been used as bait to try to attract the cartel in Sonora to them to bring the war to them. She came around a corner and they just, I mean, they just unleashed hell on this vehicle. They came up to the vehicle, shot more shots, searched, you know, rated the vehicle, and then incinerated it, set it ablaze, and burned everybody alive.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: While President Trump says it's time to wage war over the killings, Mexico's president is being criticized for his response. He's standing by government's policy of using, quote, "hugs, not bullets" when fighting these cartels.  Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas, calling out Mexico for not doing more.

utterances.speaker: SEN. TOM COTTON, R-ARK.
utterances.sentences: President Lopez's overdoors policy of hugs, not bullets.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COTTON
utterances.sentences: I mean, that may be nice for a children's fairy tale, but in the real world when the bad guys and cartels had 50 caliber machine guns the only answer is more bullets and bigger bullets. And if Mexico can't protect American citizens in Mexico, then we may have to take matters into our own hands.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, Dana, this is sort of we don't know exactly what happened, but what appears to have happened now, according to authorities is that you had one drug cartel from Juarez going to Sonora County, right, and then set up on a hill, sort of an outpost on a hill. And apparently, go after these people because they wanted to attract the opposition cartel to come in and fight.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Like using them as bait for that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, yes. Although I have to say, maybe that's all true. I think that the United States should ask for its own people to be there to do an investigation because I'm not sure that I would trust everything that the Mexican government is going to say about this, because clearly already they are saying to the president of the United States, we have -- we are good here. We don't need your help. We've got a handle on all of this. But clearly, they don't have a handle on the cartels.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right. But they did capture a suspect.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They captured a -- OK. But again, I would love for that subject to be questioned by an American interrogator. And it could be that there are Americans actually there to do that.  I go back to this idea though of what then can we do aside from going in and dealing with the cartels ourselves? But it's not like you can just take out one cartel and then the problem is over. This is a deeply entrenched problem all across Mexico.  You have 90 homicides a day. Imagine that in America, like imagine if you had 90 homicides a day, what would happen in this country. It never happened in this country. So if I were the Mexicans, I would take the president up on his offer of cooperation, it doesn't necessarily have to be made aid in terms of bullets. Maybe it is another way to help them with their governance or something, but to turn a blind eye to the United States being really frustrated on this problem, I think would leads the Mexicans down a really bad path.  I would take action as a Congress and as the president of the United States to designate the cartels as a terrorist organization. I think there is ample proof of that from the violence as well as the activities that they participate in. A $150 billion of illegal drugs coming into the country.   Now whether we legalize drugs, maybe we will do that in the future, but it's not going to happen anytime soon. So, I think that designating them as a terrorist organization right now, I think the president has a lot more tools to deal with it, it's the right thing to do.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Jesse, the issue of sovereignty does occur if you listen to what Dana was saying. Because people say well, the drug cartel activity actually crosses the border. There's a lot of drug activity and drug violence here in the United States that we have to contend with. So, how do you just go into another country and say you know what? We are coming in?

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: Now we do that all the time, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Look at American history it's what we do. You look at this guy who runs Mexico. Hugs, not bullets? It's like code pink is running the show down there. I mean, is he bought off by the cartel? I mean, that's the exact thing that the cartel wants the Mexican president to say.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Hugs, not bullets. Something really disgraceful is going on down there, and they are on thin ice. Because how many dead American are you going to tolerate. If this happens again and it happens again you could see Republican senators calling for armed action inside of Mexico. And I agree with Dana. You label them narco terrorists. You declare war not on drugs, because that's not popular.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The political winner is war on cartels. Designate them narco terrorist that gives the president enhanced power to fight the violence of trafficking and the smuggling. Because this cartel is so deeply rooted in this are you need like a counterinsurgency to then take them out. And I don't really know if this is just about drugs. Because it's also about smuggling and sovereignty. You said the guy we had on just now said that this was about one cartel fighting for a smuggling root against another cartel. That means that a wall on the southern border, Juan, in strategic locations will work. Because not all the drugs come through port of entry. They are talking about smuggling roots and not just drugs. They're talking about people.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX BUSINESS HOST
utterances.sentences: But they're talking about something roots from one part of Mexico to another. I mean, that's what this particular --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. But just south in Arizona that's where a lot of the drugs pour into, because it's so hilly and mountainous. You need walls in strategic locations. And right now, the only people who don't want walls, Democrats and the cartels.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. But then yesterday you were saying you thought the war on drugs not necessarily a winner.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't think that's a winner.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And this is and if you do go in hard, it's going to send the price of drugs skyrocketing. Greg, I mean, Greg can only afford so much. You know?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Is that right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This guy, I mean, he needs help.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right so, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Where you come out on this? Because I think you also think, war on drugs, you know, what's the point here?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, the blood lust is caused by drug lust. Right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What the cartels don't do is they don't sell pot. The reason why they don't sell anymore pot is because the U.S. competition killed the market. It used to be that pot for decades was going in one direction, north from -- north from Mexico to the United States.  Now, the retail quality of pot from the United States is going south and pot seizures is coming north has dropped by 75 percent. So, legalization killed the pot market for Mexico. I don't think you should legalize something to kill a cartel, but there is something in there that saying that cause and effect. That if you make something legal you regulated. You have an industry. You get rid of the criminal element and that's what happens.  Right now, they're just, I think they are basically dealing in Fentanyl and heroin, and probably, cocs so you could do a couple of things. One, you could kill them off like terrorists, but unlike ISIS, they make stuff we want. So, we are killing people who are essentially -- who are essentially providing something for us. With Jesse's point, number two, you could toughen the border, and you should toughen the border and that includes everything including the wall.  You can talk about decriminalization, which I think is important. Watch the drug cartels implode. But here's something that you can't do. You can't stop small religious sects from moving to a violent wasteland. You -- it puts your family and your children into harm's way. OK?  You can advise them that this is not a good idea, that this is nuts.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But they still were there. And if, you know, is this our battle? I'm not so sure this is our battle. If you're willing, you know, if you are willing to stop -- if you aren't willing to stop me from doing drugs after the show, why would you expect someone else to?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Well, why would you expect that just targeting the supply is going to affect demand at all?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: And that's the one thing that we haven't talked about --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: -- in terms of that. And so, this is the manifestation of the black market which has now reached every corridor of power in Mexico and Central America.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: And that's why we have the immigration issues that we have, because these governments have been decimated by people who just want to make money and they have to be the ones who control the market utterly. And Pablo Escobar loved the idea of legal cocaine in Colombia, because then he could sell it to anyone.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: But there is a difference if drugs are legal in the United States, because then they no longer have control over supply and demand. Do I think people should be doing drugs? I do not. I wish fewer people did drugs. But the point is they are going to. There's an appetite. We punish people and throw them in prison for making consensual transactions. Maybe we need to rethink that aspect of it and to your point, we need to talk about practically how do you get from here, which is thousands and thousands of murders to there, which is knocking off the cartels by destroying their marketplace?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Just quickly, Greg, you would not advise, this was an offshoot of the Mormons that had moved into this county. You would say don't go?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Go at your own risk.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. Big developments in the impeachment investigation.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Totally (Ph) believe.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Public hearings set for next week. The latest when “The Five” comes right back.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The Democrats taking their impeachment probe public. Shifty Schiff announcing Congress will hold open hearings next week, finally. It comes after he dump in the transcript from the testimony of top diplomat in Ukraine, Bill Taylor. Schiff claiming this new phase of the investigation will damage the president.

utterances.speaker: REP. ADAM SCHIFF, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: Those open hearings will be an opportunity for the American people to evaluate the witnesses for themselves, to make their own determinations about the credibility of the witnesses, but also learn firsthand about the facts of the president's misconduct.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK, Juan, I know you love polls, so I brought a poll for you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This is Morning Consult, very accurate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And it says support from impeachment falls as inquiry moves to a new phase. And people don't approve of the Democrat's handling of impeachment.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Your thoughts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I haven't seen that one, but I heard about it. And of course, you've got to put in a context which is that it's been in the last two months continual rise in support has largely plateaued at this juncture as we go towards the public phase of this hearing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think that the question about Bill Taylor is interesting, because Taylor is a West Point grad, a veteran, someone who is selected, almost handpicked by Secretary of State Pompeo to serve in the Trump administration.  So efforts to undermine him, to say, you know what, he is a never-Trumper. He's a bad guy. I think it's very difficult. And so, therefore, his testimony is going to have impact. And then I think the secondary argument on this one, Jesse, is but he wasn't on the call. But then you hear from others who were on the call, and you have others saying pretty much the same thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, it's just like the attack on the whistleblower --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- which has been going on. And of course, all of the whistleblowers said been corroborated.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But Trump and his guys are saying, what about the whistleblower? Like it's distraction personal attacks --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Kennedy, I feel like the Democrats had the American people's attention for a second and they totally lost it. And now no one cares about this Taylor, Volker, Sondland. That's not breaking through.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: It's not, because you don't have the big thing yet. And if you have a bunch of little things, people lose track of names, they lose track of conversations, they lose track of timelines. And that is the fault of the Democrats who have stretched this out in the wrong way. And they really should have waited until there was this formal impeachment inquiry resolution so we can have all of this in the open. But the problem is, a lot of these people have already testified and so their statements are known quantity. So now all you're going to have are Republicans and Democrats acting like show ponies just trying to out just hands each other, to play got you with the various witnesses. And I don't think we've gotten there yet. You know what it reminds me of in terms of polls? Medicare for all. Because if you ask people, should we ensure everybody?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: They go, absolutely we should. We should insure everybody. And it's the same thing. If the president did something bad, should he be impeached? Absolutely he should be impeached and he should be removed. If he did something bad, if he did something bad is the part where you have to pay for it. No one wants to pay for Medicare for all and no one has been shown that what he has done so far is absolutely 100 percent impeachable and that has to --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Bribery, not a problem?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: I'm not saying that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Bribery. I don't think we are talking about that, Juan.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Juan, I think that Rudy Giuliani has gone rouge, and I think - -

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. I'm just saying, there's a lot here.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: There's a lot there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let's get Greg in. Greg, if you are doing all of this stuff in shifty Schiff's creepy little dark basement into the capitol, I think Americans were focused for a second. Then they started thinking about football and what's going on this weekend. I think it's over now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I love these open hearings, because it's an opportunity as Schiff has said to see how petty the Democrats are and what thin gruel they're playing with. The media has replaced the Ukraine, replaced Russia with Ukraine. Yet the public isn't keen on it anymore. If you look at the left-wing media, they aren't getting that same bump that they got from the Russia stuff. And it's because it's like they are getting back together with someone who cheated on them. That's the Ukraine field. Because they got burned on Russia. Russia, they put all their hearts into Russia and it fell apart, they can't do it again with Ukraine. Because they are now beginning to see that this is a fable based on opinions, based on other opinions.  It's all about if, right? The concerned angle in which you are concerned about something that might happen but doesn't or hasn't. It's like if Donald Trump -- it goes back to one sense. If Donald Trump shot somebody on Fifth Avenue, would he get away with it? That has never happened. But that question informs the strategy, what I would call the concerned strategy, where they try to avoid the concrete achievements of Trump and replace it with hypothetical hysterics. Like, what if he does this? What if he lied? What if this was this? And also, the media wants the public to think that quid pro quo is like the plague. Actually, it's the engine of life and commerce. Whether it's sales, whether it's a politician, whether you're at, whether you got a hotdog vendor, you give me x, I'll give you y. Put some mustard on the x, please. It's part of job -- part of Trump's job to shape foreign policy based on what he feels.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Come on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He feels that he makes. No crime there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know, I just want to quickly said, Greg. Hey, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This is like Senator Graham yesterday saying it doesn't matter. It doesn't matter. I'm not reading the transcript.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: I thought that was Hillary Clinton and the Benghazi hearing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No. I'm talking about -- there you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think he speaks for a lot of Americans when he says that. Dana, Greg mentioned the strategy of the Democrats. The strategy of the Republicans I think the president could use some warriors in the morning to wake up, put the war paint on, and then fight this impeachment. The messaging, the tactics, the strategy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, one of the things --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because right now, it's just a leak, leak, leak.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, one of the ways that they could do though, is to have effective cross-examination during the public hearings. OK? Because if you read the transcript, it's like, it's not that great --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- from that perspective. So, he has to be super prepared. I was reminded by Karl Rove about Adam Schiff back in 2008. He was the new chairman. He was going to be investigating Karl Rove and they were going to get a scalp, a political scalp. And Conyers (Ph) was quoted saying they were going to get his a-s-s.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What? We got to go a break.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's what they say.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Shannon Bream didn't spell it out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And they continue in (Inaudible).

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Show it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, they go to the hearing and then Adam Schiff is actually unprepared. And like reading from the staff knows and he is not able to actually bring a sale. So now, and actually then that goes to the DOJ. The DOJ declines to prosecute. It's like this is not, this is the whole U.S. attorney thing. Now in 2019, in 10 years, when you didn't even have social media back then really, you have them -- the Democrats are planning to put on a show next Wednesday with Adam Schiff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We've been promised a show for a long time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And the bar is really, really high.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't know if they can meet the bar.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana, Dana?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Why is he the guy, though? Why is Schiff the guy? Why is he the one who is now in charge of this whole thing? Why is Adam Schiff the face --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Instead of Nadler, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, they had to do it in the dark and the intelligence committee was the only place they could pull it off. And to the people at home, we just want to apologize, you know, this is a family show.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Dana apologizes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Excuse me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana, that's really s-u-c-k-s.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, it did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Up next, Democrats all excited over last night's election. They're not going to like the latest sign that Trump is on his way to a second term. That more in a round up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Twenty-twenty round up time. First up, Democrats say last night's election results are a sign of President Trump's weakness. But a new poll shows a majority of voters do expect him to win in 2020. Fifty-six percent say they think the president will be reelected next year. Off-year elections, Jesse, is not easy to like get a sense of what could happen next year because of an off-year election. But there might have been a little -- a few tells here and there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, yes. I mean Bevin in Kentucky was very unpopular. Most unpopular governor --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I didn't know that in a country.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- in the United States and just Trump couldn't drag him across the finish line, unfortunately. But five out of the other six Republicans won in Kentucky. You know, it's not good that Republicans lost Kentucky. I'm going to be honest about it, but it is what it is. And it looks like Virginia is going blue. But the point is that Trump is going to win reelection. Moody says that if you look at all of the economic forecasts, the RNC is behind him this time. They are killing the Democrats on Facebook; they are killing them with data. And they have no talent on the left. So, I think he'll win again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Juan, the Democrats thought that they had, that they looked it the other way. Right? When you have results, everybody gets to have a say. What do you think about last night?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, first let me speak to the poll because I think that you and I have discussed this, Dana. You got an incumbent. And I think there's only two incumbents in recent history who haven't won a second term.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, most people are saying, well, yes, I guess he is the incumbent and guess what. He's quite a showman. he knows how to throw a lot of dirt. I think he's better at campaigning then he is at governing. So, he throws up a lot of dirt, calls people a lot of names, and people say, you know, if it's just him, we don't have a Democratic nominee yet. Republicans, like Jesse say, you'll be like the Democrats are more like, you know what, this guy has a real shot at reelection.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But the thing is, Kennedy, in an off-year -- since 2016 President Trump himself has not been on the ballot. That could make a difference.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Well, and also, I think it's actually good news because people are paying attention to politics in ways that they never have. And politics really, it takes up some much of our conversations and so much of our cultural focus. And so people pay attention to local races in ways they didn't before. And so, they may not like a ballot measure that you would think would go a certain way. They may not like a Republican governor in a red state, but that doesn't mean necessarily it's bad news for the president. What I will say about these two elections we're talking about, Jimmy Carter and George H.W. Bush. Jimmy Carter faced a transformational candidate in Ronald Reagan. He was a charismatic person with a solid philosophy from a big state. And he had the kind of pixie dust sprinkled over him that Jimmy Carter could only have dreamed of.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: And George H.W. Bush had Ross Perot to contend with. We haven't seen the third-party candidate like that regardless of what Hillary Clinton say about Jill Stein being a Russian asset since then.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: And you know although I love the idea of other parties --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We got another topic. We got to run to, Kennedy, is that all right? We got -- so Joe Biden slamming rival Elizabeth Warren as condescending and accusing her of elitist. Now that came after Warren said Biden was running in the wrong presidential primary for criticizing her Medicare for all. Greg, what do you make of this? Calling her an elitist?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I know. It's good to see sleepy Joe waking up though from his nap. He's got his graham crackers and his apple juice. And the thing is he needs -- this is his lane. He's still a sloppy jalopy. But he's got to get in that middle lane instead this lady is too far left for us. You know, the middle class does need Biden. They don't need a virtuous signaling clone who is going to be obedient to the squad.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. And she says, Jesse, that she was a public school teacher but she omits the part about working at Harvard.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Listen, the real punch to the face is Pocahontas. He's not going to do it, because he's afraid that he's going to lose support from liberals, if he goes after. But it's in his back pocket.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMSNEWS
utterances.sentences: Wait. But Biden did go after?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not on Pocahontas. She's fake Indian. She lied about it for her whole career. And he's waiting for that--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Jesse--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And he is going to drop it if he keeps dropping in the polls.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But Jesse, that's a petty argument.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's not a petty argument. That is a slam dunk.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know where you and I agree. Remember we were having a conversation about Medicare for All, and the idea and I think this is why Joe Biden was right to take the offensive. I'm glad to see him go out there. But guess what, people on the Left have real arguments and concerns about her Medicare for All and how it's going to be paid for.

utterances.speaker: PERINO

It never happened in this country. So if I were the Mexicans, I would take the president up on his offer of cooperation, it doesn't necessarily have to be made aid in terms of bullets. Maybe it is another way to help them with their governance or something, but to turn a blind eye to the United States being really frustrated on this problem, I think would leads the Mexicans down a really bad path. I would take action as a Congress and as the president of the United States to designate the cartels as a terrorist organization. I think there is ample proof of that from the violence as well as the activities that they participate in. A $150 billion of illegal drugs coming into the country. Now whether we legalize drugs, maybe we will do that in the future, but it's not going to happen anytime soon. So, I think that designating them as a terrorist organization right now, I think the president has a lot more tools to deal with it, it's the right thing to do.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jesse, the issue of sovereignty does occur if you listen to what Dana was saying. Because people say well, the drug cartel activity actually crosses the border. There's a lot of drug activity and drug violence here in the United States that we have to contend with. So, how do you just go into another country and say you know what? We are coming in?

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: Now we do that all the time, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Look at American history it's what we do. You look at this guy who runs Mexico. Hugs, not bullets? It's like code pink is running the show down there. I mean, is he bought off by the cartel? I mean, that's the exact thing that the cartel wants the Mexican president to say.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hugs, not bullets. Something really disgraceful is going on down there, and they are on thin ice. Because how many dead American are you going to tolerate. If this happens again and it happens again you could see Republican senators calling for armed action inside of Mexico. And I agree with Dana. You label them narco terrorists. You declare war not on drugs, because that's not popular.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The political winner is war on cartels. Designate them narco terrorist that gives the president enhanced power to fight the violence of trafficking and the smuggling. Because this cartel is so deeply rooted in this are you need like a counterinsurgency to then take them out. And I don't really know if this is just about drugs. Because it's also about smuggling and sovereignty. You said the guy we had on just now said that this was about one cartel fighting for a smuggling root against another cartel. That means that a wall on the southern border, Juan, in strategic locations will work. Because not all the drugs come through port of entry. They are talking about smuggling roots and not just drugs. They're talking about people.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX BUSINESS HOST
utterances.utterance: But they're talking about something roots from one part of Mexico to another. I mean, that's what this particular --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. But just south in Arizona that's where a lot of the drugs pour into, because it's so hilly and mountainous. You need walls in strategic locations. And right now, the only people who don't want walls, Democrats and the cartels.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. But then yesterday you were saying you thought the war on drugs not necessarily a winner.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't think that's a winner.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And this is and if you do go in hard, it's going to send the price of drugs skyrocketing. Greg, I mean, Greg can only afford so much. You know?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Is that right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This guy, I mean, he needs help.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right so, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Where you come out on this? Because I think you also think, war on drugs, you know, what's the point here?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, the blood lust is caused by drug lust. Right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What the cartels don't do is they don't sell pot. The reason why they don't sell anymore pot is because the U.S. competition killed the market. It used to be that pot for decades was going in one direction, north from -- north from Mexico to the United States. Now, the retail quality of pot from the United States is going south and pot seizures is coming north has dropped by 75 percent. So, legalization killed the pot market for Mexico. I don't think you should legalize something to kill a cartel, but there is something in there that saying that cause and effect. That if you make something legal you regulated. You have an industry. You get rid of the criminal element and that's what happens. Right now, they're just, I think they are basically dealing in Fentanyl and heroin, and probably, cocs so you could do a couple of things. One, you could kill them off like terrorists, but unlike ISIS, they make stuff we want. So, we are killing people who are essentially -- who are essentially providing something for us. With Jesse's point, number two, you could toughen the border, and you should toughen the border and that includes everything including the wall. You can talk about decriminalization, which I think is important. Watch the drug cartels implode. But here's something that you can't do. You can't stop small religious sects from moving to a violent wasteland. You -- it puts your family and your children into harm's way. OK? You can advise them that this is not a good idea, that this is nuts.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But they still were there. And if, you know, is this our battle? I'm not so sure this is our battle. If you're willing, you know, if you are willing to stop -- if you aren't willing to stop me from doing drugs after the show, why would you expect someone else to?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Well, why would you expect that just targeting the supply is going to affect demand at all?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And that's the one thing that we haven't talked about --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: -- in terms of that. And so, this is the manifestation of the black market which has now reached every corridor of power in Mexico and Central America.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And that's why we have the immigration issues that we have, because these governments have been decimated by people who just want to make money and they have to be the ones who control the market utterly. And Pablo Escobar loved the idea of legal cocaine in Colombia, because then he could sell it to anyone.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: But there is a difference if drugs are legal in the United States, because then they no longer have control over supply and demand. Do I think people should be doing drugs? I do not. I wish fewer people did drugs. But the point is they are going to. There's an appetite. We punish people and throw them in prison for making consensual transactions. Maybe we need to rethink that aspect of it and to your point, we need to talk about practically how do you get from here, which is thousands and thousands of murders to there, which is knocking off the cartels by destroying their marketplace?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Just quickly, Greg, you would not advise, this was an offshoot of the Mormons that had moved into this county. You would say don't go?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Go at your own risk.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. Big developments in the impeachment investigation.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Totally (Ph) believe.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Public hearings set for next week. The latest when “The Five” comes right back.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Democrats taking their impeachment probe public. Shifty Schiff announcing Congress will hold open hearings next week, finally. It comes after he dump in the transcript from the testimony of top diplomat in Ukraine, Bill Taylor. Schiff claiming this new phase of the investigation will damage the president.

utterances.speaker: REP. ADAM SCHIFF, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: Those open hearings will be an opportunity for the American people to evaluate the witnesses for themselves, to make their own determinations about the credibility of the witnesses, but also learn firsthand about the facts of the president's misconduct.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, Juan, I know you love polls, so I brought a poll for you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is Morning Consult, very accurate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And it says support from impeachment falls as inquiry moves to a new phase. And people don't approve of the Democrat's handling of impeachment.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Your thoughts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I haven't seen that one, but I heard about it. And of course, you've got to put in a context which is that it's been in the last two months continual rise in support has largely plateaued at this juncture as we go towards the public phase of this hearing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think that the question about Bill Taylor is interesting, because Taylor is a West Point grad, a veteran, someone who is selected, almost handpicked by Secretary of State Pompeo to serve in the Trump administration. So efforts to undermine him, to say, you know what, he is a never-Trumper. He's a bad guy. I think it's very difficult. And so, therefore, his testimony is going to have impact. And then I think the secondary argument on this one, Jesse, is but he wasn't on the call. But then you hear from others who were on the call, and you have others saying pretty much the same thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, it's just like the attack on the whistleblower --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- which has been going on. And of course, all of the whistleblowers said been corroborated.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But Trump and his guys are saying, what about the whistleblower? Like it's distraction personal attacks --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Kennedy, I feel like the Democrats had the American people's attention for a second and they totally lost it. And now no one cares about this Taylor, Volker, Sondland. That's not breaking through.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: It's not, because you don't have the big thing yet. And if you have a bunch of little things, people lose track of names, they lose track of conversations, they lose track of timelines. And that is the fault of the Democrats who have stretched this out in the wrong way. And they really should have waited until there was this formal impeachment inquiry resolution so we can have all of this in the open. But the problem is, a lot of these people have already testified and so their statements are known quantity. So now all you're going to have are Republicans and Democrats acting like show ponies just trying to out just hands each other, to play got you with the various witnesses. And I don't think we've gotten there yet. You know what it reminds me of in terms of polls? Medicare for all. Because if you ask people, should we ensure everybody?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: They go, absolutely we should. We should insure everybody. And it's the same thing. If the president did something bad, should he be impeached? Absolutely he should be impeached and he should be removed. If he did something bad, if he did something bad is the part where you have to pay for it. No one wants to pay for Medicare for all and no one has been shown that what he has done so far is absolutely 100 percent impeachable and that has to --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Bribery, not a problem?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I'm not saying that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Bribery. I don't think we are talking about that, Juan.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Juan, I think that Rudy Giuliani has gone rouge, and I think - -

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. I'm just saying, there's a lot here.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: There's a lot there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's get Greg in. Greg, if you are doing all of this stuff in shifty Schiff's creepy little dark basement into the capitol, I think Americans were focused for a second. Then they started thinking about football and what's going on this weekend. I think it's over now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I love these open hearings, because it's an opportunity as Schiff has said to see how petty the Democrats are and what thin gruel they're playing with. The media has replaced the Ukraine, replaced Russia with Ukraine. Yet the public isn't keen on it anymore. If you look at the left-wing media, they aren't getting that same bump that they got from the Russia stuff. And it's because it's like they are getting back together with someone who cheated on them. That's the Ukraine field. Because they got burned on Russia. Russia, they put all their hearts into Russia and it fell apart, they can't do it again with Ukraine. Because they are now beginning to see that this is a fable based on opinions, based on other opinions. It's all about if, right? The concerned angle in which you are concerned about something that might happen but doesn't or hasn't. It's like if Donald Trump -- it goes back to one sense. If Donald Trump shot somebody on Fifth Avenue, would he get away with it? That has never happened. But that question informs the strategy, what I would call the concerned strategy, where they try to avoid the concrete achievements of Trump and replace it with hypothetical hysterics. Like, what if he does this? What if he lied? What if this was this? And also, the media wants the public to think that quid pro quo is like the plague. Actually, it's the engine of life and commerce. Whether it's sales, whether it's a politician, whether you're at, whether you got a hotdog vendor, you give me x, I'll give you y. Put some mustard on the x, please. It's part of job -- part of Trump's job to shape foreign policy based on what he feels.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Come on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He feels that he makes. No crime there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, I just want to quickly said, Greg. Hey, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is like Senator Graham yesterday saying it doesn't matter. It doesn't matter. I'm not reading the transcript.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I thought that was Hillary Clinton and the Benghazi hearing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No. I'm talking about -- there you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think he speaks for a lot of Americans when he says that. Dana, Greg mentioned the strategy of the Democrats. The strategy of the Republicans I think the president could use some warriors in the morning to wake up, put the war paint on, and then fight this impeachment. The messaging, the tactics, the strategy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, one of the things --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because right now, it's just a leak, leak, leak.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, one of the ways that they could do though, is to have effective cross-examination during the public hearings. OK? Because if you read the transcript, it's like, it's not that great --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- from that perspective. So, he has to be super prepared. I was reminded by Karl Rove about Adam Schiff back in 2008. He was the new chairman. He was going to be investigating Karl Rove and they were going to get a scalp, a political scalp. And Conyers (Ph) was quoted saying they were going to get his a-s-s.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What? We got to go a break.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's what they say.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Shannon Bream didn't spell it out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And they continue in (Inaudible).

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Show it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, they go to the hearing and then Adam Schiff is actually unprepared. And like reading from the staff knows and he is not able to actually bring a sale. So now, and actually then that goes to the DOJ. The DOJ declines to prosecute. It's like this is not, this is the whole U.S. attorney thing. Now in 2019, in 10 years, when you didn't even have social media back then really, you have them -- the Democrats are planning to put on a show next Wednesday with Adam Schiff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We've been promised a show for a long time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And the bar is really, really high.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know if they can meet the bar.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana, Dana?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Why is he the guy, though? Why is Schiff the guy? Why is he the one who is now in charge of this whole thing? Why is Adam Schiff the face --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Instead of Nadler, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, they had to do it in the dark and the intelligence committee was the only place they could pull it off. And to the people at home, we just want to apologize, you know, this is a family show.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Dana apologizes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Excuse me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana, that's really s-u-c-k-s.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, it did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Up next, Democrats all excited over last night's election. They're not going to like the latest sign that Trump is on his way to a second term. That more in a round up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Twenty-twenty round up time. First up, Democrats say last night's election results are a sign of President Trump's weakness. But a new poll shows a majority of voters do expect him to win in 2020. Fifty-six percent say they think the president will be reelected next year. Off-year elections, Jesse, is not easy to like get a sense of what could happen next year because of an off-year election. But there might have been a little -- a few tells here and there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, yes. I mean Bevin in Kentucky was very unpopular. Most unpopular governor --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I didn't know that in a country.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- in the United States and just Trump couldn't drag him across the finish line, unfortunately. But five out of the other six Republicans won in Kentucky. You know, it's not good that Republicans lost Kentucky. I'm going to be honest about it, but it is what it is. And it looks like Virginia is going blue. But the point is that Trump is going to win reelection. Moody says that if you look at all of the economic forecasts, the RNC is behind him this time. They are killing the Democrats on Facebook; they are killing them with data. And they have no talent on the left. So, I think he'll win again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan, the Democrats thought that they had, that they looked it the other way. Right? When you have results, everybody gets to have a say. What do you think about last night?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, first let me speak to the poll because I think that you and I have discussed this, Dana. You got an incumbent. And I think there's only two incumbents in recent history who haven't won a second term.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, most people are saying, well, yes, I guess he is the incumbent and guess what. He's quite a showman. he knows how to throw a lot of dirt. I think he's better at campaigning then he is at governing. So, he throws up a lot of dirt, calls people a lot of names, and people say, you know, if it's just him, we don't have a Democratic nominee yet. Republicans, like Jesse say, you'll be like the Democrats are more like, you know what, this guy has a real shot at reelection.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But the thing is, Kennedy, in an off-year -- since 2016 President Trump himself has not been on the ballot. That could make a difference.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Well, and also, I think it's actually good news because people are paying attention to politics in ways that they never have. And politics really, it takes up some much of our conversations and so much of our cultural focus. And so people pay attention to local races in ways they didn't before. And so, they may not like a ballot measure that you would think would go a certain way. They may not like a Republican governor in a red state, but that doesn't mean necessarily it's bad news for the president. What I will say about these two elections we're talking about, Jimmy Carter and George H.W. Bush. Jimmy Carter faced a transformational candidate in Ronald Reagan. He was a charismatic person with a solid philosophy from a big state. And he had the kind of pixie dust sprinkled over him that Jimmy Carter could only have dreamed of.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And George H.W. Bush had Ross Perot to contend with. We haven't seen the third-party candidate like that regardless of what Hillary Clinton say about Jill Stein being a Russian asset since then.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And you know although I love the idea of other parties --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We got another topic. We got to run to, Kennedy, is that all right? We got -- so Joe Biden slamming rival Elizabeth Warren as condescending and accusing her of elitist. Now that came after Warren said Biden was running in the wrong presidential primary for criticizing her Medicare for all. Greg, what do you make of this? Calling her an elitist?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know. It's good to see sleepy Joe waking up though from his nap. He's got his graham crackers and his apple juice. And the thing is he needs -- this is his lane. He's still a sloppy jalopy. But he's got to get in that middle lane instead this lady is too far left for us. You know, the middle class does need Biden. They don't need a virtuous signaling clone who is going to be obedient to the squad.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. And she says, Jesse, that she was a public school teacher but she omits the part about working at Harvard.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Listen, the real punch to the face is Pocahontas. He's not going to do it, because he's afraid that he's going to lose support from liberals, if he goes after. But it's in his back pocket.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMSNEWS
utterances.utterance: Wait. But Biden did go after?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not on Pocahontas. She's fake Indian. She lied about it for her whole career. And he's waiting for that--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jesse--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And he is going to drop it if he keeps dropping in the polls.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But Jesse, that's a petty argument.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's not a petty argument. That is a slam dunk.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know where you and I agree. Remember we were having a conversation about Medicare for All, and the idea and I think this is why Joe Biden was right to take the offensive. I'm glad to see him go out there. But guess what, people on the Left have real arguments and concerns about her Medicare for All and how it's going to be paid for.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, Bill Galston of the Wall Street Journal wrote today that her plan is the longest political suicide note in history.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, it could be. But what I'm saying is you have Joe Biden there. He can say, this is where you and I agree, fix Obamacare, make it work, right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's a nice attack. I mean elitism in the Democratic primary just seems soft compared to what we went to 2016.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Elitism?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's not a really nasty attack. I want to see more blood.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know what, you want a better nickname. That's what you want. All right, finally, Senator Kamala Harris introducing a bill that would make the school day 10 hours long, to better sync up with parents work schedules. Doors would be open from 8 AM to 6 PM, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. I read something on Twitter today that kind of blew my mind. A guy named Frank J. Fleming just tweeted some casual tweet. He said, if you put a child through 16 years of education, at the end you would have Batman. I mean when you think about it. But after 16 years, we're grateful that this kid could write a blog or sell hot tubs. Technically, 16 years of actual real education, you should have a Navy SEAL who can play classical violin, but we don't - I mean think about 16 years. You put somebody through 16 years of real education that tells you we have to re-evaluate education. It's not about more Kamala. It's about better. So, you've got to forget courses. We've got to get rid of courses and focus on talent. So, imagine a six-year-old being told that by the time you're 21, you're going to be a highly skilled martial artist who will be able to play guitar as well as Jimi Hendrix and have a degree in engineering. You should have all of those things.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I just want to say on the--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Let's ask a mom on the panel. Kennedy, what do you think about this idea?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Well, we don't have that because we don't allow kids to follow their passion.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: So, kids don't develop skills deeply like they should.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Because we're resting on this outdated Prussian 19th century factory model. It does a great disservice and Kamala Harris only wants to extend that. We need school choice and we do need to completely rethink the education system.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I agree with the school choice thing, but why is it when attacking Kamala Harris This is a good idea. Bernie Sanders had the same idea and not only did Bernie Sanders not get the blowback that she's getting, I think every mother in America who has to deal with childcare after school says, oh, yes, that's a rational idea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But she does love putting kids away.
